params.text:
Reading

Use Keys To Understand Words

Language in Action

• Understand the word in context
  • Recognise the word (part of speech)
  • Decode the word (prefixes and suffixes)
Reading: Introduction

In this module, you'll learn some tricks to unlock the meaning of words in your reading. 

Here's what we'll cover:

1. Understanding Words in Context: We'll explore how the words around a new word can help you guess its meaning.

  2. Word Detectives: Learn how to identify the part of speech (noun, verb, adjective) to understand a word's function in a sentence.

  3. Prefix & Suffix Power: Discover how prefixes (added before a word) and suffixes (added after a word) can change a word's meaning!
Understand The Words In Context: Key Points

Ever come across a new word while reading?
Don't worry, you can be a detective and figure it out!

Please click on the information points to see useful strategies:
Look Around the Word:
Think of Similar Words:
• Sometimes, there might be a word nearby that has a similar meaning.
• The words before and after a new word can be clues to its meaning.
Check for Opposites:
• If there's a word like "not" or "opposite" before a new word, it means the opposite of a familiar word.
Understand The Words In Context: Opinions

params.textField: "I don't know a word in an *email*? No problem! I read the sentence *around* it. If it says 'meeting tomorrow,' the new word must be about the *meeting* time or place."

params.textField: "Sometimes at work, I see a long word with 'un-' at the *beginning*. This helps! It usually means the *opposite*. 'Unhappy' means not happy, so 'uncomfortable' must *mean* not comfortable."

metadata.title: Understand The Words In Context Abigail - Drag the Words

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Micah is reading an email about a meeting. She sees a new word, but he can understand it from the words around it. What does Micah do?
answers:
She looks for clues in the sentence about the meeting. 

She asks his coworker for the definition. 

She ignores the new word and continues reading.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Abigail sees a long word with "un-" at the beginning in a work document. What does she do to understand the meaning?
answers:
She remembers that "un-" often means the opposite. 

She sounds out the word letter by letter.

She skips the word and moves on to the next sentence.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Anthony is reading a report with a new word ending in "-ment." What can he guess about the word?
answers:
It's probably an action you take, like "development" or "improvement." 

It describes a person, like "teacher" or "student." 

It's something you can hold, like a "book" or "pencil."

metadata.title: Understand The Words In Context - Quiz

params.text: Understand The Words In Context: Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question:
Recognise The Word (parts of speech): Key Points

Grammar can seem tricky, but don't worry! We can be detectives and figure out what kind of word we're looking at (like a noun, verb, or adjective). 

Here are some clues:
Action Words:
People or Places:

• These words name things. They can be people, animals, objects, or places.
    Example: John sent a letter to Miami. ("John" is a person and "Miami" is a place.)

• These words tell you what's happening! They often end in "-ing" but not always.
    Example: "The computer is working well today." ("Working" tells you what the computer is doing.)
Describing Words:

• These words tell you more about people, places, or things.
    Example: The delicious pizza arrived at our hungry office. ("Delicious" describes the pizza and "hungry" describes the office workers.)
Recognise The Word (parts of speech): Opinions
Micah:
Abigail:
Bryan:
Please listen to the opinions and fill in the missing words:

params.textField: "In work *reports*, I see words that describe things, like '*efficient*' or 'reliable.' These must be *adjectives* because they add details to the nouns."

metadata.title: Recognise The Word  Abigail - Drag the Words

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: The company is located in New York City. What type of word is "New York City"?
answers:
A noun because it names a place.

An action word because it tells you what the company does. 

A describing word because it gives details about the location.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: John sent an email yesterday. What type of word is "sent"?
answers:
An action word because it tells you what John did.

A describing word because it describes John. 

A noun because it names something John did.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: We received a delicious pizza for lunch. What type of word is "delicious"?
answers:
A describing word because it describes the taste of the pizza. 

An action word because it describes something we did to the pizza. 

A noun because it names a type of food.

metadata.title: Understand The Words In Context - Quiz

params.text: Recognise The Word (parts of speech): Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question:
Decode The Word (prefixes and suffixes): Key Points

Words can be like puzzles! Sometimes, they have little pieces at the beginning (prefixes) or end (suffixes) that can help you solve their meaning.

Here are some tips:
Prefixes:
Suffixes:

• A suffix is a tiny clue at the end of a word. It can tell you something about the word's function!
    Example: "Play" is an action, a verb. But "player" is the person who does the action, a noun, because of the suffix "-er".

• A prefix is like a tiny clue at the beginning of a word. It can change the word's meaning!
    Example: "Happy" means good or joyful. But "unhappy" means the opposite, not happy, because of the prefix "un-".
Recognise The Word: Sentences

He is *unhappy* because his team lost the match
They *reheated* the meal in the microwave
John is very *impatient*. He hates to wait for things
Colin is a fireman, so he has an *irregular* sleep pattern
Stealing money is *illegal*

metadata.title: Decode The Word 1 - Drag the Words

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: You see a new word in a sentence. The sentence says "The meeting starts at 10:00 AM. John will send a summary. " What can the new word after "a" tell you?
answers:
Maybe it has something to do with the meeting.

The color of the summary.

The time of the meeting.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: You see the word "computer" in a work email. What type of word is "computer"?
answers:
A noun because it names a place or thing.

An action word because it tells you what to do. 

A describing word because it describes something.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: You hear your coworker say "discuss" during a meeting. What type of word is "discuss"?
answers:
An action word because it tells you what people are doing.

A describing word because it describes the meeting.

A noun because it names something people talk about.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: You see the word "unlock" on your phone. What does the prefix "un-" mean in this word?
answers:
Not something. 

To do something again. 

To make something bigger.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: You received a work email with the word "attachment." What can the suffix "-ment" tell you about this word?
answers:
It's something that is attached to the email.

It describes the email. 

It's an action you take with the email.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: Your manager gave a presentation about a new product. What can the suffix "-tion" tell you about the word "presentation"?
answers:
It's the act of showing something, like the new product. 

It describes the new product. 

It's a person who works on presentations.
